title: Haman's Plot Against the Jews
shortSummary: In Esther chapter 3, Haman is elevated to a position of great power but becomes enraged when Mordecai refuses to bow to him. This personal offense leads Haman to plot the destruction of all the Jews in the Persian Empire, resulting in a royal decree that sets a tragic day for their annihilation. The chapter highlights themes of pride, prejudice, and the unfolding of God's providential plan.
timeline: c. 5th century BC - Persian Empire under King Ahasuerus

keyCharacters.name: Haman
keyCharacters.description: An Agagite elevated by King Ahasuerus who becomes the antagonist by plotting to destroy the Jewish people.

keyCharacters.name: Mordecai
keyCharacters.description: A Jew who refuses to bow to Haman, sparking Haman's wrath and the subsequent decree against the Jews.

keyCharacters.name: King Ahasuerus
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king who grants Haman authority and unknowingly sanctions the decree to destroy the Jews.

definitions.definition: A descendant of Agag, king of the Amalekites, enemies of Israel; symbolizing longstanding enmity toward the Jews.
The lot cast by Haman to determine the date for the destruction of the Jews, symbolizing fate or divine judgment.
A large unit of weight and money in the ancient world; ten thousand talents of silver was an enormous sum.
The royal signet ring used to seal official decrees, signifying the king's authority and approval.

outline.heading: Haman Elevated and Mordecai's Defiance
outline.description: King Ahasuerus promotes Haman above all princes, and all bow to him except Mordecai, who refuses out of loyalty to God. Haman's anger leads him to seek not only Mordecai's death but the destruction of all Jews, revealing the dangers of pride and hatred.

outline.heading: Casting of the Pur and Haman's Proposal
outline.description: Haman casts lots (Pur) to choose the date for the Jews' destruction and presents his plan to the king, portraying the Jews as a threat to the kingdom. This section shows how personal vendetta escalates into a national crisis.

outline.heading: The King's Decree Against the Jews
outline.description: King Ahasuerus authorizes Haman to execute his plan, giving him the king's ring to seal the decree. The edict is sent throughout the empire, setting a day for the annihilation of the Jews, which causes distress in the capital city of Shushan.

application: Stand firm in your faith and obedience to God even when pressured to conform to ungodly demands, as Mordecai did.
Recognize the destructive power of pride and hatred, and guard your heart against bitterness that can lead to harm against others.
Pray for wisdom and courage to confront injustice and for God's protection over His people in times of trial.
Trust in God's sovereign providence even when circumstances seem dire, knowing He can turn evil plans to good.

keyVerses.text: And when Haman saw that Mordecai bowed not, nor did him reverence, then was Haman full of wrath.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the root cause of Haman's hatred and the ensuing conflict, emphasizing the spiritual battle behind earthly events.

keyVerses.text: If it please the king, let it be written that they may be destroyed: and I will pay ten thousand talents of silver to the hands of those that have the charge of the business, to bring it into the king's treasuries.
keyVerses.significance: Haman's offer shows his greed and determination to destroy the Jews, illustrating how sin often involves selfish ambition.

keyVerses.text: Then were the king's scribes called on the thirteenth day of the first month, and there was written according to all that Haman had commanded unto the king's lieutenants, and to the governors that were over every province, and to the rulers of every people of every province according to the writing thereof, and to every people after their language; in the name of king Ahasuerus was it written, and sealed with the king's ring.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the official and irrevocable nature of the decree, setting the stage for the crisis that will test God's people.
